intro: Gilia pungens subsp. pulchriflora, commonly known as the showy gilia, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the family Polemoniaceae and is characterized by its striking, tubular, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and has hairy stems and leaves adapted to arid conditions. Its flowers are often visited by hummingbirds and bees, making it an important pollinator resource. The subspecies is distinguished by its more showy and larger flowers compared to other subspecies of Gilia pungens.
